quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I'm a big proponent of asking myself, if I'm not getting the reaction that I'm looking for, how might I be contributing? How could I explain this more clearly? How can I be more compelling? How can I anticipate any questions that they might have?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical self-audit for taking responsibility for confusion and improving clarity and persuasion.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I think the blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that small communication mistakes can create outsized downstream costs.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you are just shooting off a message in a Slack channel with 15 other people, and it's confusing, you didn't include information you should have included, there's going to be a bunch of back and forth. Whereas if you had just taken another look at it, those 15 people would be off to the races.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A concrete example showing how a quick revision can prevent costly coordination churn across a group.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: MOO stands for Most Obvious Objection.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A memorable framework for anticipating and addressing predictable pushback before it derails a meeting.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When really, if you thought for even two minutes about what are obvious objections that I'm likely to get, you often immediately come up with what some of those things are.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to spend a small amount of time pre-empting the most likely questions and objections.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: Highlights a predictable inflection point for SaaS teams: enterprise customer demands for identity/provisioning features.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Warrant's product is based on a groundbreaking authorization system called Zanzibar, which was originally designed for Google to power Google Docs and YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: Points to a proven, large-scale authorization model (Zanzibar) as a foundation for fine-grained access control.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: Captures the key tradeoff solved by modern authorization systems: scale plus flexibility for complex permissions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's a drop-in replacement for Auth0 and supports up to 1 million monthly active users for free.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (WorkOS read)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption/ROI data point that can influence build-vs-buy decisions for auth infrastructure.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: When it comes to ensuring your company has top-notch security practices, things get complicated fast.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Vanta read)
quotes.context: A concise reminder that security/compliance complexity accelerates quickly, motivating early investment in systems and automation.

quotes.topic_title: Why communication is high-leverage for leaders
quotes.text: There's this quote that Boz, the CTO of Meta, he's been on the podcast, he wrote this famous blog post, "Communication is the job."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable leadership mental model that frames communication as the core responsibility, not a supporting skill.

quotes.topic_title: Why communication is high-leverage for leaders
quotes.text: "Wes single handedly raised the quality of the entire company's writing by like two X across the board. I always say the best writing course I ever took was working with Wes for a year."
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete example of communication as a high-leverage force multiplier with a specific “2X” impact claim.

quotes.topic_title: Why communication is high-leverage for leaders
quotes.text: I often see operators who explain things poorly and then are shocked and horrified when people are confused or there's skepticism, there's apathy, there's a lot of avoidable questions, and I'm a big proponent of asking myself, "If I'm not getting the reaction that I'm looking for, how might I be contributing to that?"
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical self-audit prompt that shifts responsibility to the communicator to diagnose and improve outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why communication is high-leverage for leaders
quotes.text: So, you know, instead of blaming other people for not understanding me, I think about how could I explain this more clearly? How can I be more compelling? How can I anticipate any questions that they might have?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: An actionable checklist for improving clarity and influence by preempting confusion and objections.

quotes.topic_title: Why communication is high-leverage for leaders
quotes.text: So I'm a big proponent of agency. And realizing that we can only control our own behavior. And so the best place to start, if you're not getting the reaction you're looking for, is reflecting on how can I get better at the skill of communicating? And it absolutely is a skill.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A counter-to-blame mindset that emphasizes controllables and treats communication as a learnable, improvable skill.

quotes.topic_title: Agency: if they don’t get it, adjust you
quotes.text: I'm a big proponent of asking myself, "If I'm not getting the reaction that I'm looking for, how might I be contributing to that?"
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical self-audit question that shifts you from blaming others to improving your own communication inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Agency: if they don’t get it, adjust you
quotes.text: So, you know, instead of blaming other people for not understanding me, I think about how could I explain this more clearly? How can I be more compelling? How can I anticipate any questions that they might have?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A concrete checklist of levers (clarity, persuasion, anticipation) to reduce confusion and skepticism before it happens.

quotes.topic_title: Agency: if they don’t get it, adjust you
quotes.text: So I'm a big proponent of agency. And realizing that we can only control our own behavior.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A mental model for “managing up” that focuses on controllables rather than others’ reactions.

quotes.topic_title: Agency: if they don’t get it, adjust you
quotes.text: You can't solve everything with improving your communication, but you can increase the likelihood of getting what you want.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A grounded, probabilistic view of communication as leverage—imperfect but high-impact.

quotes.topic_title: Practice like it’s game day with everyone
quotes.text: I think another big one that I teach in my course and really kick off with is practicing like it's game day, playing like it's game day.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Introduces a simple mental model for treating everyday communication as high-stakes practice.

quotes.topic_title: Practice like it’s game day with everyone
quotes.text: So I see a lot of operators who save their best behavior for executives only.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Calls out a common (and costly) pattern that limits growth in executive-level communication.

quotes.topic_title: Practice like it’s game day with everyone
quotes.text: And I just don't think that you're going to be able to get enough reps to actually get good at executive communication if you are only doing it with executives.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Frames executive communication as a reps-based skill that requires frequent practice beyond exec audiences.

quotes.topic_title: Practice like it’s game day with everyone
quotes.text: Because many of us only present to execs once a month, right? Or a couple of times a quarter.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Gives a concrete frequency example showing why relying on exec moments alone is too infrequent for skill-building.

quotes.topic_title: Practice like it’s game day with everyone
quotes.text: So really treating every single stakeholder as if they are important because they are, and you shouldn't be if you don't want to waste your CEO's time, you also shouldn't waste your cross-functional team members' time or your manager's time or your direct reports' time.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Extends the 'respect exec time' principle to everyone, turning everyday interactions into deliberate practice.

quotes.topic_title: What counts as communication: verbal, written, outcomes
quotes.text: Yeah, I would say broadly the two mediums are verbal communication and written.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A simple, practical umbrella model that helps practitioners categorize and choose the right channel for a message.

quotes.topic_title: What counts as communication: verbal, written, outcomes
quotes.text: And I also think about communication as more of a means to an end, which might be interesting for some people because I teach a course on communication.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Reframes communication from a skill to perfect into a tool to achieve outcomes, which can change how you plan and evaluate it.

quotes.topic_title: What counts as communication: verbal, written, outcomes
quotes.text: So you would think that's like the end in and of itself, but I really see it as a means to an end where the end is getting the ideal outcome you're looking for.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: judge communication by whether it produces the desired outcome, not by how polished it is.

quotes.topic_title: What counts as communication: verbal, written, outcomes
quotes.text: So whether that is buy-in or making a good decision as a team or moving to the next step, whatever that might be, communication is really in service of that end goal.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Gives concrete outcome targets (buy-in, decisions, next steps) that practitioners can use to define success for any communication.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in before details
quotes.text: So a common mistake that I see is overestimating the amount of buy-in that you have from your audience.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Highlights the root cause behind why detailed process explanations often fall flat: you may not actually have agreement yet.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in before details
quotes.text: A sales note is meant to get people excited to do the thing you want them to do, and to agree to do it. And only then after they have bought in, does it make sense to share the logistics.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Defines a practical sequencing framework—sell first, then share implementation details—to increase alignment and follow-through.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in before details
quotes.text: So there's an order of operations here. If you switch the order of operations, you will likely get a slow response or just no response, right? We've all put a Slack message in a channel and got crickets and tumbleweed.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Connects the “sales then logistics” model to a common real-world failure mode (messages that get ignored) and why it happens.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in before details
quotes.text: Yeah. So I actually think that you should always do a little bit of selling even for situations where people have generally bought in.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance: even after prior agreement, you still need to re-sell briefly because attention and context decay over time.

quotes.topic_title: Sales then logistics: earn buy-in before details
quotes.text: So I'm not talking about spending 15 minutes out of a 30 minute meeting selling, I'm talking about one to two minutes, even a couple sentences, and then transitioning into the main thing you want to talk about.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Gives an actionable time-boxed tactic for how to “sell” without derailing exec-focused conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Concise framing for execs and “yes, next” mindset
quotes.text: And then I also like asking or stating what I need from the other person upfront.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A simple tactic for aligning expectations early so the listener knows exactly how to engage and what decision/feedback is needed.

quotes.topic_title: Concise framing for execs and “yes, next” mindset
quotes.text: So like that was like 15 seconds, right? Super fast.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark/example showing that effective framing can be done in seconds, not minutes or slides.

quotes.topic_title: Concise framing for execs and “yes, next” mindset
quotes.text: Yeah. So I call it the yes, yes, yes, next, next, next mindset where if I'm listening to direct reports present something to me, very often I find myself thinking, "Got it. All right, yes, let's keep going." Right?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how leaders process information quickly, which explains why presenters must front-load clarity and decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Concise framing for execs and “yes, next” mindset
quotes.text: And sometimes they would give me buy or make the decision by slide four, you know?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A specific example illustrating that execs may decide far earlier than your planned narrative, so you must adapt in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Concise framing for execs and “yes, next” mindset
quotes.text: And what was really helpful for me was realizing that I should take the win. Okay, if five seconds already agreed, take the win and keep it moving, move on.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to stop selling once you have agreement, preventing over-explaining and preserving momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Being concise: clarity of thinking and preparation
quotes.text: And being concise is not about absolute word count, it's about economy of words. It's about the density of the insight that you're sharing.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Reframes concision as insight density rather than brevity, changing how you evaluate and edit communication.

quotes.topic_title: Being concise: clarity of thinking and preparation
quotes.text: And all of these pithy aphorisms assume that you actually know what your core point is. So you can't cut to the chase unless you know what the chase is. You can't unbury the lead unless you know what the lead is.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Identifies the hidden prerequisite to being concise: clarity on the core point before trying to “get to it.”

quotes.topic_title: Being concise: clarity of thinking and preparation
quotes.text: And so that I found is the bottleneck to being concise. It's actually not really being clear of what you are thinking, that's what's leading to being long-winded.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Pinpoints the root cause of rambling as unclear thinking, not a failure of editing or speaking technique.

quotes.topic_title: Being concise: clarity of thinking and preparation
quotes.text: And so the only solution I found consistently to being concise is preparation.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Offers a practical lever—pre-meeting prep—as the most reliable way to improve concision in real time.

quotes.topic_title: Being concise: clarity of thinking and preparation
quotes.text: So if you even take 30 seconds to one minute to ground yourself on why am I in this meeting? What do I want to share and make sure I get across in the time that we have, you're going to go in there so much more focused and so much more able to be concise.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, low-effort pre-meeting routine that directly improves focus and brevity.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load, blast radius
quotes.text: I also ask myself, how might I be adding cognitive load to whatever it is that I'm saying?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical self-check that helps you tighten writing by focusing on reader effort, not just word count.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load, blast radius
quotes.text: And usually when I do that, I end up trimming 20% at least of what I wrote, tightening up some sentences.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A concrete benchmark that makes concision measurable and motivates a quick editing pass.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load, blast radius
quotes.text: There's a layer of advice under this that you're not saying that I'm going to say, which is actually look at the thing you wrote at least once before you share it.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A simple, high-leverage habit that prevents avoidable confusion and errors before they spread.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load, blast radius
quotes.text: Going back to something that you were saying earlier with rereading what you wrote, I think the blast radius of a poorly written memo is way bigger than most people think.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for the hidden organizational cost of unclear writing across many readers.

quotes.topic_title: Concise writing: reread, reduce cognitive load, blast radius
quotes.text: So I think about that a lot too. It's not just me writing this and sending it off. It's, "Who are all the people who are going to come in contact with this message who are going to refer to it and use it? And if I just take 30 more seconds to make sure that it's clean, how much can I unblock from their work?"
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Reframes editing as a force-multiplier: small extra effort can unblock many people downstream.

quotes.topic_title: Signposting and formatting: guide attention without clutter
quotes.text: Signposting is using certain words, phrases, formatting, and an overall structure in your writing that helps guide your reader and signals what is coming in the rest of the post.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Defines a practical communication technique for structuring long memos so readers can follow where you’re going.

quotes.topic_title: Signposting and formatting: guide attention without clutter
quotes.text: If you kick off sentences with signposting words, you can often signal, "Here's what I'm about to talk about in this paragraph."
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Gives an immediately applicable tactic: use signposting words to create structure without relying on heavy formatting.

quotes.topic_title: Signposting and formatting: guide attention without clutter
quotes.text: I've seen memos where 30% of the note was bolded. And that just negates the entire point of bolding because if everything is bolded then nothing is being highlighted, right?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A concrete example that challenges the common instinct to add more emphasis via formatting.

quotes.topic_title: Signposting and formatting: guide attention without clutter
quotes.text: So that's I think a great litmus test of, "Was that idea fully thought out?" Because if it was, you should be able to really quickly turn it into a complete sentence.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Offers a simple test for clarity: if you can’t write it as a full sentence, the thinking may be incomplete.

quotes.topic_title: Signposting and formatting: guide attention without clutter
quotes.text: And it feels faster and more concise to put bullets and fragments, but a lot of times your reader on the other end of that is needing to decipher and interpret and guess what you actually meant. So it net, net takes longer.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Counterintuitive point: bullet fragments can increase total time by shifting cognitive work to the reader.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: Yeah. So I have a pretty first principles driven approach for this, which is to think about how long does it take me right now to get to the reaction I'm looking for from my recipient? If it takes a bunch of back and forth and a bunch of friction, then that's my baseline. And once you start practicing some of these communication skills, how does that speed up? If you would have had seven different touch points of back and forth, does that shrink to two to three?
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A measurable feedback loop for communication effectiveness: track speed-to-desired-reaction and reduction in back-and-forth.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: I do think that being fascinated by a topic and being excited about it makes it more likely that you're going to find it fun to try all these different things and try different ways to get through to people. So, I would approach it with a hypothesis-driven experimental mindset and almost like a game. Like, "When I do this, how does that other person react? If I frame it this way, do I get a different reaction? When I try this, am I able to cut through the noise more?"
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Treat communication improvement as iterative experimentation—run “framing” tests and observe reactions like a game.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: And I will say that the way not to do it is to try to incorporate 30 different tactics at the same time and then beat yourself up when you don't remember to do them.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical warning against overwhelm: focus on one tactic at a time to build habits sustainably.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: The problem with that line of thinking is that no one instance of something is ever going to feel important enough to spend a little bit more time on that. And then, but when you zoom out, that's like, "Well that's all your work then. This is literally everything you've touched. This is all your work output then."
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: small communication artifacts are “all your work output,” so marginal effort compounds.

quotes.topic_title: How to practice: measure speed to desired reaction
quotes.text: I like thinking about it as a little bit more upfront investment. And it is an investment. It's not just time. It's an investment because yes, it takes a little bit longer to make a Slack message a little bit better, but net, net if you save a bunch of questions and back and forth and people asking you things that you don't think they should be asking, then by investing a little bit of upfront effort, you've prevented all that from happening.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A cost-benefit model for clarity: spend slightly more time upfront to reduce downstream churn and interruptions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Imagine starting a project at work and your vision is clear. You know exactly who's doing what and where to find the data that you need to do your part.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concrete picture of what “good” project alignment looks like—clear ownership and easy access to needed information.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In fact, you don't have to waste time searching for anything because everything your team needs from project trackers and OKRs to documents and spreadsheets lives in one tab all in Coda.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable operational principle: reduce coordination cost by centralizing key artifacts in a single source of truth.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And more than 50,000 teams trust Coda to keep them more aligned and focused.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point used to support credibility and social proof.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And she said you had zero half-baked thoughts, 100% complete sentences, perfect punctuation, clear takeaways at the top of every message.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A memorable standard for written communication in Slack: lead with takeaways and write in fully-formed, polished sentences.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: It's the kind of thing you don't notice in isolation, but once you see everyone else's messages in a remote-first company, it's a stark contrast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Counterintuitive observation that communication quality becomes much more visible—and differentiating—in remote-first environments.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence calibration: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: So I'm a big proponent of speaking accurately. You can avoid a lot of problems if you speak accurately about your level of conviction and about the actual amount of evidence that you have for something.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A core principle for calibrating confidence: match your language to your actual certainty and evidence so others can evaluate appropriately.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence calibration: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: So people who are too confident might state hypotheses as if they are fact. So that really bothers me. That's another one of my pet peeves, where if you say, "This is X," or, "This will X," that is different than saying, "This could X," or, "This might X," or, "This will increase the likelihood of X."
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A practical language-level tactic for avoiding overconfidence by explicitly signaling probability rather than certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence calibration: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: And y'all might spend real headcount and dollars pursuing something that you have advocated for in a way where you overreached with your level of confidence.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Highlights the real organizational cost of overstating certainty—misallocation of time, people, and budget.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence calibration: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: And so again, speaking accurately, if you have really strong reasons to recommend something to the cross-functional team, it's almost irresponsible to act like you are not really sure and it's just this random idea, "Hey, try it if you want to."
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: Counterbalances overconfidence by arguing that excessive disclaimers can be harmful when you actually have strong conviction and reasoning.

quotes.topic_title: Confidence calibration: speak accurately about certainty
quotes.text: Yeah, I think sharing a point of view, sharing a recommendation, and then backing it up with evidence, with logic, with first principles, with examples, with data, if you have it.
quotes.speaker: Wes Kao
quotes.context: A repeatable methodology for persuasive communication: POV + recommendation + explicit reasoning/evidence (including first principles when data is missing).
